textline.text: Jacqueline A. Siapno, Ph.D.
Curriculum Vitae
Current Contact address:
1417 Rose Glen Drive
Roseville, California 95661
E-mail: jasiapno@gmail.com
Website: https://independent.academia.edu/JacquelineSiapno
Work Affiliation:
Independent Researcher; Co-founder: Centro Para a Mulher e Estudos do Genero,
Dili, Timor Leste (East Timor).
Education. Degrees:
1997 Ph.D. Degree Awarded at University of California-Berkeley, USA.
Department of South and Southeast Asian Studies.
Dissertation on “Gender, Islam, Nationalism and the State in Aceh, Indonesia: The Paradox of
Power, Co-optation, and Resistance.” Published by RoutledgeCurzon 2002.
1990 M.A. Degree , School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, England.
Area Studies (Southeast Asian Politics). M.A. Thesis on “Islamic Resistance Movements and the
Conflict over Natural Resources in Mindanao, Southern Philippines.”
1989 B.A. Degree, Wellesley College. Massachusetts, USA.
Major: Political Science.
1985. Graduated from Mt. Eden High School, Hayward, California Public School System.
1981. Graduated from Elementary School and First-year high school, Edna’s School, Dagupan
City, Pangasinan, Philippines.
Work Experience and Professional Commitments:
Keynote Speech. Canadian Council for Southeast Asian Studies. University of Ottawa, Canada.
“Reversing the gaze” and paper for workshop on “Memory, Truth, and Reconciliation: Coming
to terms with the past”, Oct. 15-17, 2015. See: https://ccseas2015.wordpress.com/keynote/
Visiting Professor, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University, Japan.
October 1, 2012-April 30, 2013. Research on International Climate Change Mitigation and The
Military in Politics.
Associate Professor, Graduate School of International Studies, Seoul National University, South
Korea. September 2009-February 2012. Developed, taught, lectured on new courses and
supervised M.A. and Ph.D. graduate students and their Dissertations.
Co-founder, Vice-Rector I, and Lecturer, Universidade Dili (UNDIL) and Universidade da Paz
(UNPAZ), Dili, Timor Leste, June 2002-2004; reduced my tenured position in University of
Melbourne in order to be able to commute and support this university and the new nation-state
building programs in East Timor; set up the Faculty of Social Sciences and Humanities; helped
build the university library; was responsible for Curricular Development and at the same time
Curricular Reform; recruited Faculty and Deans.
Assistant Professor. Lecturer Level B (Tenured position); June 2000-September 2007. Joint-
Appointment, School of Politics and Public Policy, Sociology and Criminology and The Asia
Institute (MIALS), Sidney Myer Asia Centre, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria,
Australia.
Associate Editor, with Professors Suad Joseph, Afsaneh Najmabadi, and others. Responsible for
regional entries on Southeast Asia, Australia and the Pacific. Encyclopedia of Women and
Islamic Cultures (EWIC) Project, Volumes 1-6, 1999-2006. Leiden: Brill Academic Publishers.
Travelled to Editorial Meetings for 7 years, including to Egypt, Boston, and San Francisco.
Collaborated with hundreds of scholars working on “Women and Islamic Cultures” and read/
edited hundreds of scholarly articles on Family Law, Sexualities, Gender Studies, Performing
Arts, Politics, and other thematic topics.
Principal Researcher, “Engendering Security Sector Reform (SSR): from Military Security to
Human Security,” commissioned by the National Planning Commission of Timor Leste and the
Ministry of Defense, for the State of the Nation Report and input into the National Strategic
Development Plan, Timor Leste, 2008.
Fieldwork Research in Aceh, Medan and Jakarta, Indonesia for Amnesty International Report on
“Shock Therapy: Restoring Order in Aceh,” 1993. Conducted ethnographic research on state
terror and violence in rural villages and the impact of major economic and environmental
changes (oil extraction by Jakarta and foreign companies, deforestation) on local livelihoods, in
Aceh and Medan, Sumatra, Indonesia.
Founder and Teacher, “Music Studio for Cello and Piano”, Delta 1, Dili, Timor Leste, July 2013-
August 2014. Teaching music education, harmony, harmonization, and “international cooperation
without domination” to youth and kids, through solo and ensemble/chamber music; using music
education as an anti-poverty program for inclusive development in rural districts; performing in
public concerts to benefit rural youth’s educational-cultural programs in Timor Leste and the
Philippines. For our Music Education Program in Timor Leste, see for example “Music Syllabus:
Piano and Cello Lessons as Life Lessons” in my academia.edu website:
https://independent.academia.edu/JacquelineSiapno; for some of our community performances
in Southeast Asia, please see youtube.com: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYGJvK9gj10
See also: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8jNCTD-5ww
Campaign Trainer for Transformative Leadership and Public Speaking/Fundraiser/Political
Adviser, Partido Democratico, for Presidential Elections in March 2012 and Parliamentary
Elections in July 2012, Timor Leste.
Lecturer, Faculty of Economics and Faculty of Social and Political Sciences; organized seminars
and fieldwork with School of Democratic Economics; Universidade Nacional Timor Leste
(UNTL), January 2008-August 2009.
Visiting Professor, Master’s Program in Peace, Conflict and Development, UNESCO Chair of
Philosophy for Peace. Universitat Jaime, Castellon (near Barcelona), Spain, 2007 (one month);
and 2008 (one month). Taught and supervised graduate students and their theses.
Luce Post-Doctoral Fellow, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies (RSPAS) and Faculty
of Asian Studies, Australian National University, Canberra. 1999-2000.
Post-Doctoral Fellow, University of California-Irvine, Humanities Research Institute. Nine-
months Residential Seminar on "Gender and Citizenship in Muslim Communities", directed by
Suad Joseph, with Sondra Hale, Islah Jad, Jasamin Rostam-Kolayi, Ula Taylor, Kristy Bright,
and Carol Bruch; Sept. 1998-May 1999.
Visiting Professor, Dept. of Women's Studies, University of California-Riverside, August-
December 1997.
Research Fellow, University of California-Irvine Humanities Research
Institute. Six-months Residential Seminar on "Feminism and Discourses of Power"
directed by Judith Butler and Wendy Brown, with Nancy Fraser, Saidiya Hartman, Anne
Norton, Angela Harris, Irene Wei, Nancy Campbell, Rey Chow, and Jenny Sharpe; January-June
1991 - 1992 Teaching Assistant, Tagalog Language Class. University of California- Berkeley.
Other Positions
Acting First Lady, East Timor (Timor Leste), and supporting my late husband in his different
political, state and government positions (1999-2015). See: “In Memoriam, Fernando La Sama
de Araujo”: www.rappler.com/views/imho/99074-fernando-la-sama-de-araujo-in-memoriam
Book Reviewer for various journals: Southeast Asian Studies Journal, Kyoto; Southeast Asia
Research; Journal of Asian studies, Feminist Review; Sojourn; and other journals.
External Reviewer for Ph.D. and M.A. Dissertations, for several universities in East Asia (Korea,
Japan), Southeast Asia (Indonesia, the Philippines, Timor Leste), the US, and Australia (Perth,
Canberra, Melbourne).
Evaluator, Trainer, and Adviser for International Organizations, including: Oxfam (on Gender
and Transformative Leadership); UNIFEM (Women and Political Ethics); UNDP (Gender
Adviser); Concern Worldwide (Rural Development). Timor Leste, 2001-2010.
Government Ministries: Policy Analysis, Researcher, Writer, Trainer: on “Knowledge
Economies” for Commision on Anti-Corruption (CAC) in Timor Leste; Casa Militar, Office of
the President (on Timor Leste’s Accession to ASEAN); Ministry of Defense (on Security Sector
Reform); National Commission on Planning (on the State of the Nation Annual Report and the
National Strategic Development Plan); Ministry of Foreign Affairs (on ASEAN), in Timor Leste.
Non-governmental organizations: public seminars and workshops on governance (at Luta
Hamutuk, Timor Leste); Truth and Reconciliation Commissions and Human Rights (Aceh
Institute, Banda Aceh, Indonesia); on Women’s Rights and Family Law (Fokupers, Timor Leste):
from 1998-present.
Courses Taught: undergraduate and graduate; and outside the university
Introduction to Reflexive Sociology
Sociological Theory
Philosophies on Ethics and Care of the Self
Indigenous belief systems and practices in Southeast Asia
Critical studies on displacement, migration, crossing-borders
Critical Studies of Development Administration: “The Dark Side of Giving” and creating
cultures of dependency
Political economy of international climate change mitigation
Research Methodologies (Qualitative, Interviewing, and Ethnographic Methods)
New Methods in Linking Research and Public Policy
Comparative Politics
Political Economies of Southeast Asia
International Relations
Language and Power
Global Inequalities
School of Democratic Economics
Human Rights Theory and Practice
The US at War in East Asia and Southeast Asia
Feminist Theory
Muslim Political Thought
Global Governance and Human Security
Environmental Studies and Resource Politics
Gender and International Development
International Organizations and Post-War, Post-Conflict Reconstruction and Development
Gender, Transformative Leadership, and Ethics in Public Policy
Bringing the Middle East into the Study of Southeast Asian Islam
Mental Health in Post-War, Post-Conflict Environments
Democracy, Diversity, Inequality, and Social Justice
Engendering Security Sector Reform
Modern Indonesian Literature (in Bahasa Indonesia)
Classical Malay Literature (in Malay)
Philippine Literatures (in Tagalog and Pangasinan)
Feminism/s and Discourses of Power
Knowledge, Power, and Sexuality
Gender and Citizenship in Muslim Communities
Militarized Masculinities
State and Sexuality
Philosophies of Peace, Ethics, and Care of the Self
Supervision and Mentoring of M.A. and Ph.D. students in a wide range of multidisciplinary and
interdisciplinary research projects: at Graduate School of International Studies, Seoul National
University; Universitat Jaume I in Castellon, Spain (UNESCO Chair of Philosophy for Peace);
Universidade Nacional Timor Leste (UNTL); University of Melbourne: in Sociology;
Comparative Politics; International Relations; Political Theory; Political Economy; Public Policy
and Administration; Global Environmental Politics; Global Inequalities; Organizational
Behavior; Organizational Development; Political Psychology; Critical Studies of International
Development; Research Methods; Environment, Social Justice; Gender Studies and Feminist
Theories; Critical Race Theory; Islamic Studies; Colonial and Post-colonial Studies; Rhetoric
and Communication; Transnational Studies; Applied Ethics; Global Governance; Security Sector
Reform; Human Rights.
Selected Publications
For some publications and writing samples, please see: http://independent.academia.edu/
JacquelineSiapno
Interview in Social Text, with Professor Neferti Tadiar, “Siding with the dispossessed,” see:
http://socialtext-dev.cdrs.columbia.edu/siding-with-the-dispossessed-interview-with-jacqueline-
aquino-siapno/ March 16, 2012.
“Shari’ah Law and the Politics of Consent in Aceh, Indonesia,” in Social Differences online,
edited by Lila Abu-Lughod and Anupama Rao, Center for Critical Study of Social Differences,
Columbia University, 2012.
“On Race and Racism/s: Representations of Southeast Asians in Korean Cinema,” Paper
presentation, Southeast Asian Studies Conference in Sogang University, Seoul, South Korea,
Interview with Noam Chomsky on “Language and Power,” in Balon Silew (Pangasinan Journal,
Philippines), July 2011.
“Timor Leste’s Preparation for Accession into ASEAN,” in Journal of Critical Asian Studies,
“Knowledge Economies in Timor Leste,” (published in Tetun), in Journal of the Commission on
Anti-Corruption (CAC), Timor Leste, 2013.
Between Knowledge and Commitment: Post-Conflict Reconstruction and Peace-Building in
Regional Contexts. Masako Ishii and Jacqueline Siapno, eds. Osaka: Japan Centre for Area
Studies, 2004.
“From Guerrillas to State Bureaucrats, Civilians, and Members of Parliament,” in Timor
Contemporaine, edited by Frederic Durand and Christine Cabasset; translated to French;
Bangkok: IRASEC, 2014.
Book Review, "Freedom in Entangled Worlds: West Papua and the Architecture of Global
Power," by Eben Kirksey. N.C.: Duke University Press, 2012. Book review published in Sojourn,
Book Review of “Mapping the Acehnese Past,” by Michael Feener, Anthony Reid, et.al., in
Southeast Asia Journal, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University, August 2013.
“Political Spousehood for Dummies: An Insider’s View,” in “Everyday Coloniality: How Wars
End,” edited by Alf Luedtke, Michael Kim, Eve Rosenhaft, et.al, forthcoming 2015.
Gender, Islam, Nationalism and the State: The Paradox of Power, Cooptation and Resistance.
RoutledgeCurzon, 2002.
Associate Editor, “Methodologies, Paradigms, and Sources,” Encyclopedia of Women and
Islamic Cultures, Volumes 1-6, with Suad Joseph, Afsaneh Najmabadi, Julie Peteet, Seteney
Shami, and Jane Smith. Leiden: Brill, 2003; Volume II: Family, Law, and Politics. Leiden: Brill,
2005; also Volumes III-VI.
“A Society with Music is a society with hope: Musicians as Survivor-Visionaries in Post-war
Timor Leste,” in South East Asia Research, September 2013.
“Dance and Martial Arts in Timor Leste: Resilience and “Speaking Beyond Trauma” in a
Conflict Environment,” in Journal of Intercultural Studies, Special Issue on Dance, 2012.
“Are there Good Samaritans,” in Asian Journal of Women’s Studies, S. Korea: EWHA
University, 2011.
Living Through Terror: Everyday Resilience in Timor Leste and Aceh,Indonesia,” in Living
Through Terror Special Issue of Social Identities,”and also a book, edited by Suvendrini Perera
and Antonio Traverso, Routledge, 2010.
“Timor Leste: On a Path of Authoritarianism?,” in Journal of Southeast Asian Studies, 2006.
“The Politics of Reconstruction, Gender, and Re-integration in Aceh,” in Tsunami in a Time of
War: Aid, Activism, and Reconstruction in Sri Lanka and Aceh, edited by Malathi de Alwis and
Eva Lotta Hedman, International Center for Ethnic Studies, 2009.
"The Disciplinary Field of Political Science: Sources and Methods for Research on Women and
Islamic Cultures," in Encyclopedia of Women and Islamic Cultures. Leiden: E.J. Brill, Volume I,
Associate Editor, Encyclopedia of Women and Islamic Cultures (EWIC). Volume I:
Methodologies, Paradigms, and Sources. General Editor: Suad Joseph. Leiden: Brill, 2003;
Volume II: Family, Law, and Politics. Leiden: Brill, 2005. Siapno, Jacqueline, Suad Joseph,
Afsaneh Najmabadi, Juli Peteet, Seteney Shami, editors. 2006. "Economics, Education, Mobility
and Space," V olume IV , Encyclopedia of Women and Islamic Cultures. Leiden: Brill; up to
Volume VI.
“The Bitter Taste of Victory,” Inside Indonesia. July-August 2006.
Principal Researcher and Writer. UNDP Timor Leste, Governance Unit. With Ana Paula da
Costa, National Gender Officer, UNOTIL, Sebastiana Pereira, Gender Affairs Associate, UNDP,
Armindo dos Santos, Gender Research Assistant, UNDP “Review of UNDP Timor Leste: The
consequences of overlooking women and gender: why certain development schemes to improve
the human condition have failed. An ethnography of institutional processes through a gendered
lens.” UNDP internal document, 2006.
"Gender, Nationalism and the Ambiguity of Female Agency in Aceh and East Timor", in
Frontline Feminisms: Women, War and Resistance, Marguerite Waller, Jennifer Reycinga, and
Chandra Mohanty (eds.). Routledge, 2000.
"Alternative Filipina Heroines: Contested Tropes in Leftist Feminisms," in Bewitching Women,
Pious Men: Gender and Body Politics in Southeast Asia, Aihwa Ong and Michael Peletz (eds.).
University of California-Press, 1995.
"Gender Relations and Islamic Resistance in Mindanao, Philippines," in Muslim Women's
Choices: Religious Belief and Social Reality, Camilla Fawzi el-Sohl and Judy Mabro (eds.).
Oxford and London: Berg Publishers, 1993.
Awards/Fellowships
Kyoto Research Fellowship, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University, 2012-2013.
Seoul National University Research Grant, 2009-2010.
Australian Research Council Grant, 2006-2008: Dance, Movements, and Visual
Symbolism in East Timor.
UNESCO Grant, 2004-2005 for research on shared dance traditions in Southeast
Asia.
Awarded Melbourne Research Development Grant (MRDG) on “Islam, Piety and Militancy in
Southern Philippines and Southern Thailand” for 2001-2002.
Awarded ARC (Australian Research Council) Grant to conduct research on
“Women, Sustainable Development, and Local Governance”: A Comparative Study of
the Philippines and East Timor for 2002-2003.
Luce Post-Doctoral Fellowship in Southeast Asian Studies. Research School of Pacific
and Asian Studies and Faculty of Asian Studies, Australian National University,
Canberra, Australia, September1999-May 2000.
Post-Doctoral Teaching and Research Fellowship. Humanities Research Institute,
University of California-Irvine. September 15, 1998-June 15, 1999. Teaching in the Dept.
of East Asian Languages and Literatures. Member of the Residency Seminar on “Gender
and Citizenship in Muslim Communities” directed by Suad Joseph.
Dissertation Writing Fellowship. Department of South and Southeast Asian Studies
Block Grant and Vice-Chancellor’s Research Award. University of California-Berkeley,
January 1997-June 1997.
Dissertation Fellowship. Social Science Research Council (SSRC) and American Council of
Learned Societies. Fieldwork in Aceh, Sumatra, Indonesia from January 1996-December
1996. The fieldwork was sponsored by the Indonesian Institute of Sciences (Lembaga
Ilmu Pengetahuan Indonesia) and the Indonesian/Aceh Council of Ulama (Majelis
Ulama Aceh/Indonesia.)
Foreign Language and Area Studies Fellowship (FLAS) for Dutch Language Study,
Rijksuniversiteit Leiden (Netherlands). Language study and archival research in Leiden,
Amsterdam and The Hague, July-December 1995.
Resident Fellow. Humanities Research Institute, University of California-Irvine. Member
of Group Seminar “Feminism and Discourses of Power”, directed by Judith Butler and
Wendy Brown, January-June 1995.
Foreign Language and Area Studies Fellowship (Full-year FLAS) for Malay/Indonesian
Language Training, 1992-1993, 1993-1994, U.C. Berkeley.
Foreign Language and Area Studies Fellowship (Summer FLAS) for Advanced Portuguese,
Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal, June-August 1994.
Social Science Research Council Pre-Dissertation Fellowship. Preliminary fieldwork in Aceh
and extensive travel in Indonesia, June-August 1993.
Barnette Miller Prize for best paper in International Relations and Comparative Politics,
Department of Political Science, Wellesley College, May 1989.
Public Lectures, Public Policy-relevant teaching and training:
“Timor Leste’s preparation for accession into ASEAN: public participation, production of
knowledge/s, comparative histories and perspectives from below,” Paper Presented to Panel on
“Timor Leste’s Accession into ASEAN,” Casa Militar, Office of the President, Timor Leste, June
Public talks, interviews on: “Sustainable Development”; “Transformative Leadership”; “Women
and Political Ethics”; “Strengthening Anti-Corruption Mechanisms,” in various media including
Al Jazeera, Arirang TV (Seoul, S. Korea); Radio Televisaun Timor Leste; Philippine Daily
Enquirer and other international fora.
Trainer and Facilitator, Civil Society, University, and international and local NGO discussions on
“Governance and Sustainable Development”, “Engendering Human and Food Security”,
“Women’s Economic Empowerment”, “International Human Rights Theories and Practices”, and
“Inequality and Democratic Governance” in Timor Leste, Aceh, Indonesia, Thailand, S. Korea,
Japan, and the Philippines (including for Fokupers, Luta Hamutuk, Aceh Institute, Forum on
Philippine Alternatives, and many others).
Research with Dr. Hendro Sangkoyo, Founder of School of Democratic Economics (based in
Jakarta, Indonesia) on “Language and Power”, “Climate Change” and “Humans and the
Environment” in Timor Leste and Southeast Asia, 2007-present.
Invited Paper, “Precarious Reconstruction(s), Contested Development(s): Decolonizing Gender
Discourse(s) and Reading Competing Islamist Presentations and Re-presentations in Aceh,” First
International Conference of Aceh and Indian Ocean Studies. Organized by Asia Research
Institute, National University of Singapore & Rehabilitation and Construction Executing Agency
for Aceh and Nias (BRR), Banda Aceh, Indonesia, 24 – 27 February 2007.
Invited Paper, “Shattering Silence: Articulating Women’s Experiences of Violence” in
Conference on “The Peace Process in Aceh,” Asia Center, Harvard University, Oct.24-27, 2007.
“Some people don’t seem to know why they are here: the need for new paradigms in Security
Sector Reform, Peacekeeping and Peacebuilding,” Paper presented at Conference on “War and
our World,” in a Panel on “The Geo-politics of Peacekeeping” with Goldie Osuri (Macquarie
Univ., Sydney), Manchester University, July 2007.
Office of the Ombudsman, Victoria and Office of the Ombudsman, Thailand: Invited Trainer for
one-week workshop on “Transformative Leadership and Gender” and “Advanced
Investigations,” Melbourne, 9-13 Oct. 2006. Worked with/ trained 15 Thai civil servants from
Office of the Ombudsman, Thailand.
Member, Working group on "Re-examining the Philippine Left", Forum on Philippine
Alternatives, with Dr. Walden Bello (Director, Focus on the Global South); and Coordinator of
Gender Workshop, UC Berkeley, 1994.
United Nations Development Program (UNDP) Timor Leste (East Timor) Gender Adviser/
Coordinator of the Gender Thematic Trust Fund Program. July-Dec. 2005.
Responsible for conducting a gender audit of UNDP Timor Leste programs;
a gender analysis of all fifty program policies and their implementation in the rural districts;
facilitating and conducting training for UNDP staff; and preparing a UNDP
country gender strategy for East Timor.
Fokupers (local East Timorese women’s NGO) and UNIFEM Timor Leste.
Consultant. Program on “Women’s Political Participation in the 2007 Elections.”
Identified potential women candidates from the various political parties,
independent candidates, national public figures; organized a national conference
in Hotel Timor in Jan. 2006, and facilitated four focus group discussions on the above topic.
Prepared a report on the conference. Jan. 2006.
UNIFEM, Invited Trainer, project with Timor Institute of Development Studies (TIDS): “Basic
Gender Sensitivity Training,” including “Evolution of critical approaches to women’s
participation WID, WAD, and GAD”; and “Feminist Research Methodologies,” Jan. 2006.
UNDP. Consultant. Commission on Planning on "Capacity Development in the Government and
Public Sector". Conducted interviews with government departments of civil servants at Levels 5,
6, and 7 (including Dept. of Education, Health, Justice, Finance, Foreign Affairs, Office of the
Inspector General, Infrastructure and Public Works, and others). Sept.-Dec. 2001.
Oxfam. July - Sep 2002 Consultant and Trainer, on Gender and Rural Development and
Environmental Health.
Concern Worldwide. Oct - Dec 2001 External Evaluator. Conducted an External Evaluation for
Concern Worldwide, East Timor on their "Rural Development and Empowerment of Women
Program" in seven villages in Lautem and seven villages in Ainaro. October 21-Dec. 19, 2001.
Field research in Lautem, Ainaro and Dili. Completed a report on: "Counter-mapping Gender
and Development in East Timor".
UNIFEM. 2004. On “Women and Political Ethics”, Suco Elections for 2004-2005. TV (RTTL)
Panelist. “Feto iha politika ho etika politika” with the Adviser to the Prime Minister,
Office for the Promotion of Equality, Maria Domingas Alves (Mana Micato), former
Minister of Foreign Affairs, Jose Ramos-Horta, Director of CAUCUS, Teresinha Cardoso,
and Director of STAE, Tomas Cabral. 26 Feb. 2004.
Workshop Coordinator, Feto Democratico, Organizacao Mulheres Democratico, Ermera, March
2006 on “Women’s Political Participation in the 2007 Elections.” Organizing village women in
the women’s section of Partido Democratico to prepare for the 2007 elections.
Guest Speaker. “Hametin Ukun An ho Spiritu Foun.” Annual Congress, RENETIL (Resistencia
Nacional dos Estudantes de Timor Leste.) May 7-9 2004.
Guest Speaker, Baucau Community Center, “How to Read and Interpret Political Polls,”
organized by IRI, Nov. 2003.
Member, "Japan-Australia Working Group on Rivals to the Nation-State in Southeast Asia," with
Southeast Asianist scholars from ANU including Prof. Reynaldo Ileto, Prof. Ben Kerkvliet and in
conjunction with Prof. Moto Uchibori and scholars in Japan from Tokyo University, Japan
Center for Area Studies (Osaka). 2000-2001.
Collaboration with Gekidan Kaitaisha: Theater of Deconstruction.
The Center for Contemporary Arts, Chapter Arts, Cardiff. Invited as Artist in Residence.
Contributed ideas and performed in “Dream Regime” workshop and theater performance,
Cardiff, Wales. January 5-25, 2004. Segments of this theatre performance included
representations of East Timor history and politics.
Co-founder, with Jafar Siddiq Hamzah, and Acehnese community in New York: International
Forum for Aceh (IFA). First international conference on Aceh, held at the New York University
(NYU) Asia-Pacific American Studies Program. Dec. 1998. IFA then went on to organize
international conferences on Aceh in Bangkok, Japan, Banda Aceh, Jakarta, New York again, and
other places.
“Reflections” on International Women’s Day, Discussant, Assosiasaun Hak and Fokupers, Dili,
Timor Leste, 6 March 2008.
“Building Incapacity: The Tragic Outcomes of UN and East Timor Government’s
Shortsightedness,” Public Lecture, Dept. of Political Science and Sociology, Univ. of Melbourne
Guest Speaker, “Strengthening Women’s Political Participation in Political Parties,” Organizacao
Mulheres Democratico, Partido Democratico conference, Gleno, Ermera, Timor Leste, Feb.
“Socio-political and economic contexts of Bioethics in Southeast Asia: a critique of “hegemonic
development”, “ Paper presented to “Bioethics Training Program”, University of the Philippines-
Manila College of Medicine, 11 March 2005 Philippine General Hospital, 2005.
“Nations from out of revolution: Health Care challenges in East Timor,” (including re-building
state health system and policies; actions of international health and financial institutions with
implications to national sovereignty; indigenous beliefs of resilience and care of the self). Paper
presented to “Bioethics Training Program,” University of the Philippines-Manila College of
Medicine, 14 March 2005, Philippine General Hospital.
“Women as survivor-visionaries, peace-makers and instruments of violence,” ANU, Centre for
Conflict and Post-Conflict Studies, “Conflict and Peace- keeping in the Asia-Pacific: Lessons
Learned,” 21-22 October 2004.
“Barriers to Women’s Participation in East Timor,” Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology,
Globalism Institute. October 25, 2004.
“The role of investigative journalism in the democratization process,” Conference on “Media and
Democratization,” Hotel Timor, Dili, Timor Leste, Sponsored by JICA and Associacao
Jurnalistas Timor Leste, 2004.
“Actualizing the Political Body in East Timor,” UK Chapter Arts, Cardiff, Wales, with Gekidan
Kaitaisha (Theatre of Deconstruction, Japan), Jan. 2004.
“Who Sustains Whose Development,” Conference on “Between Knowledge and Commitment”,
January 17-19, sponsored by Japan Center for Area Studies, Sophia University and Japan
Ministry of Education, 2003.
“Challenges to Education in East Timor,” Invited Guest Speaker, Symposium on “War and
Peace”, Scripps College, Claremont Colleges, California, USA. Sept. 18-20, 2002.
Guest Speaker, Asosiacao Journalistas de Timor Leste, at a workshop on The Role of the Free
Press in Post-Conflict, Independent East Timor, Knua Buka Hatene, August 15, 2002.
“Security Issues in the Philippines” and “Re-definitions of Security in Southeast Asia from a
Gendered Perspective”, Centre for Strategic and Defense Studies, June 7, Canberra, Australia,
“Power, Hegemony, and Muslihat in Aceh”, paper presented to conference on “Old Selves, New
Selves: The Politics of Identity in Indonesia,” University of Tasmania, Launceston, December,
“Dismantling the Master’s House: War, Peace, and Survival in Aceh and East Timor,” paper
presented to the Association of Australian Social Scientists, November 2000.
“Graffiti for a Truer Kind of Politics: Death, Revenge, and Building in East Timor,” ASAA
Conference, University of Melbourne, July 3-5, 2000.
“Beyond Centre-Periphery: Women at the Margins of Politics in Aceh,” paper presented to
conference on “Rethinking Indonesia”, organized by Melbourne- Indonesia Consortium, 2000.
“Women, NGOs, and those things that cannot be inventoried in Aceh,” paper presented to
Monash Southeast Asia Lecture Series, October 2000.
“Beyond Centre-Periphery: Women at the Margins of Politics in Aceh,” paper presented to
conference on “Rethinking Indonesia”, organized by Melbourne- Indonesia Consortium, March
Public Lecture, “Autonomy, Federation, Independence: Comparative Perspectives on Aceh and
East Timor,” with Fernando de Araujo and Amrih Widodo, Faculty of Asian Studies, Australian
National University, November 18, 1999.
Public Lecture, “The Problem of Power in History and Historiography,” Southeast Asia History
Group, Faculty of Asian Studies, Australian National University, November 5, 1999.
Co-Organizer with Rene Lysloff, Symposium on “Political Performativity in Indonesia and East
Timor: Acts of Representation, Repression, Resistance”, with Pramoedya Ananta Toer,
University of California-Riverside, UC Riverside Department of Music, UC Riverside Center for
Ideas and Society and University of California Pacific Rim Initiative, May 21, 1999.
Co-Organizer/Speaker with Jafar Siddiq Hamzah and John Kuo Wei Tchen, International
Conference, “Years of Living Dangerously: The Struggle for Justice in Aceh, Indonesia Beyond
Suharto,” New York University, Asia/Pacific/American Studies Institute, Dec. 12, 1998.
“Feminism and Social Movements in Southeast Asia,” Public Lecture, San Diego State
University, Dec. 7, 1998.
Guest Speaker (in Bahasa Indonesia), “Human Rights in Aceh and Indonesia”, Indonesian
Mosque, Astoria, Queens, New York, August 30, 1998, invited by Indonesian religious leaders in
New York.
Radio Interview (Indonesian language), “Women and Human Rights in Aceh and Indonesia,”
Radio Netherlands, August 7, 1998.
Public Lecture, “Gender and Politics in Indonesian Nationalism(s)”, Conference on “Women and

Other Interests and Commitments.
Languages; Pangasinan and Tagalog (Philippine languages) - mother tongues
Malay and Indonesian - speaking, reading and writing fluency
Jawi (Arabic script of Malay) - reading ability.
Tetun – reading, writing, and speaking fluency. East Timorese Citizenship.
Studied the following languages: Dutch, French, Arabic, Acehnese, Portuguese, Korean.
Aikido Martial Arts (Japanese martial arts; intensive training since August 2007).
Cellist; Pianist; Music Educator (solo piano and cello and ensemble-chamber music).
